1.text: I tell the truth in Christ. I am not lying and my conscience bears witness with me in the Holy Spirit

2.text: that I have great sorrow and unceasing pain in my heart.

3.text: In fact, I could wish that I myself were accursed from Christ for the sake of my brethren, my relatives according to the flesh,

4.text: who are Israelites. Theirs is the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the offering of divine service, and the promises.

5.text: From them are the fathers and Christ according to the flesh, who is blessed God over all, unto the ages. Amen.

6.text: But it is not as though the word of God has come to nothing. In fact, those of ‘Israel’ are not all Israel,

7.text: and just because they are Abraham’s seed, not all are children. But, “In Isaac will your seed be called.”

8.text: That is, it is not the children of the flesh who are children of God, but the children of the promise are considered as descendants.

9.text: For this is a word of promise, “At the appointed time I will come, and Sarah will have a son.”

10.text: Not only so, but Rebecca also conceived by our father Isaac.

11.text: Even before her twins had been born or had done anything good or bad (so that God’s purpose of election might stand, not of works, but of him who calls),

12.text: it was said to her, “The elder will serve the younger.”

13.text: As it is written, “Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.”

14.text: What then shall we say? That there is injustice with God? May it never be!

15.text: For God said to Moses, “I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”

16.text: And so, it is not about someone willing or running, but it depends on God who has mercy.

17.text: Thus, the Scripture says to Pharaoh, “For this very purpose, I caused you to be raised up, so that I might show in you my power, and that my Name might be proclaimed in all the earth.”

18.text: And so, God has mercy on whom he desires, and he hardens whom he desires.

19.text: You will then ask me, “Why does God still find fault? Who can resist his will?”

20.text: But who indeed are you, a human being, to argue with God? Will the thing formed ask the one who formed it, “Why did you make me like this?”

21.text: Does not the potter have a right over the clay, to make from the same lump one part a vessel for honor, and another for dishonor?

22.text: What if God, willing to show his wrath and also to make his power known, endured with much patience vessels of wrath fitted for destruction;

23.text: and that he might make known the riches of his glory on vessels of mercy, which he prepared beforehand for glory?

24.text: That is us, whom he also called, not from the Jews only, but also from the Gentiles?

25.text: As he says also in Hosea:  I will call them ‘my people,’ which were not my people;   and her ‘beloved,’ who was not beloved.

26.text: It will be that in the place where it was said to them,   ‘You are not my people,’   There they will be called ‘children of the living God.’

27.text: Isaias (Isaiah) cries concerning Israel:  If the number of the children of Israel are as the sand of the sea,   It is the remnant who will be saved;

28.text: For he will finish the work and cut it short in righteousness,   Because the Lord will make a short work upon the earth.

29.text: As Isaias (Isaiah) has said before:  If the Lord of Hosts had not left us a seed,   We would have become like Sodom,   And would have been made like Gomorrah.

30.text: What then shall we say? That the Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, [still] attained to righteousness, even the righteousness which is of faith;

31.text: but Israel, pursuing a law of righteousness, did not in fact arrive at the law of righteousness.

32.text: Why? Because they did not seek it by faith, but by the works of the law! For they stumbled over the stumbling stone,

33.text: even as it is written:  Behold, I lay in Zion a stumbling stone and a rock of offense;   And whoever believes in him will not be disappointed.
